source.value: Pathfinder Adventure: The Fall of Plaguestone

description.value: This large crossbow is harder to load and more substantial than a regular crossbow, but it packs a greater punch.
The blade of this footâ€‘long knife curves inward and lacks a cross guard at the hilt.

The thick second skin of the armor disperses blunt force to reduce bludgeoning damage. You gain resistance to bludgeoning damage equal to 1 + the value of the armor's potency rune for medium armor, or 2 + the value of the armor's potency rune for heavy armor.
Shorter than traditional arrows but similar in construction, bolts are the ammunition used by crossbows.
A healing potion is a vial of a ruby-red liquid that imparts a tingling sensation as the drinker's wounds heal rapidly. When you drink a healing potion, you regain the listed number of Hit Points.

After you drink this mutagen, your body becomes thick and sturdy. You exhibit a healthy glow, though you tend to be ponderous and unobservant. The bonus is +1, you gain 5 temporary Hit Points, and the duration is 1 minute.

After you drink this mutagen, your body becomes thick and sturdy. You exhibit a healthy glow, though you tend to be ponderous and unobservant. The bonus is +1, you gain 5 temporary Hit Points, and the duration is 1 minute.

Trigger Hallod scores a critical hit with a melee attack.

Effect Hallod can attempt an Athletics check to Shove or Trip the target of his attack. This uses the same multiple attack penalty as the attack, but it does not count as an additional attack for that penalty

Hallod makes two Strikes, one with each hand; he usually attacks first with his kukri. If this first attack hits, the target is flat-footed to the second attack (which for Hallod is usually a fist Strike). The multiple attack penalty applies to these attacks as normal
Hallod deals 1d6 extra precision damage to flat-footed creatures.
